question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
You have a square that has a side length of $1$ centimeter. Each minute, $2$ centimeters are added to the side length. After $10$ minutes, what will be the difference between the area of the last square and the area of the initial square in square centimeters (do not include the units in your answer)?
inference:
The initial area is $1^2 = 1$ square centimeter.

After $10$ minutes, each side will have $10 \times 2 = 20$ centimeters added to it, making the new side length $21$ centimeters.

The new area will be $21^2 = 441$ square centimeters.

The difference between the new area and the initial area is $441 - 1 = 440$ square centimeters.

Final Answer: $\boxed{440}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: The initial square has area $1^2 = 1\text{ cm}^2$. After ten minutes, the side length of the square will be $1 + 2\cdot 10 = 21\text{ cm}$. So, the last square has area $21^2 = 441\text{ cm}^2$. So the difference in areas is $441 - 1 = \boxed{440\text{ cm}^2}$.
